symptoms.name: Fatigue
symptoms.pattern: Present in approximately 40% of symptomatic cases, typically 1-3 weeks post-exposure

symptoms.name: Cough
symptoms.pattern: Present in approximately 40% of symptomatic cases, typically 1-3 weeks post-exposure

symptoms.name: Dyspnea
symptoms.pattern: Present in approximately 40% of symptomatic cases, typically 1-3 weeks post-exposure

symptoms.name: Headache
symptoms.pattern: Present in approximately 40% of symptomatic cases, typically 1-3 weeks post-exposure

symptoms.name: Night sweats
symptoms.pattern: Present in approximately 40% of symptomatic cases, typically 1-3 weeks post-exposure

symptoms.name: Myalgias
symptoms.pattern: Present in approximately 40% of symptomatic cases, typically 1-3 weeks post-exposure

symptoms.name: Rash
symptoms.pattern: Present in approximately 40% of symptomatic cases, typically 1-3 weeks post-exposure

vital_signs.description: Not specified in provided text, but severe cases may present with abnormal vital signs indicative of respiratory distress or sepsis

serologic_tests.IgG: Allows for assessment of disease severity

lab_values.culture: Can be performed on tissue and respiratory specimens, but sputum culture can be difficult
lab_values.microscopy: Can detect spherules in tissue or respiratory secretions; low sensitivity
lab_values.urinary_antigen: Not widely used, may be useful in immunocompromised patients with severe disease
lab_values.PCR: FDA-approved PCR available for detection from lower respiratory specimens

risk_factors: Occupations and activities increasing dust exposure (construction, excavation, dust storms)
Immunocompromised states (HIV, diabetes, hematologic malignancies, organ transplant, corticosteroid use)

required: Positive serologic tests (IgM and/or IgG antibodies)
